title.narrative: The WOZO Haiti Program Addressing Trauma

description.narrative: Community Health Worker, Clergy/Lay Leaders, Farmers, Out of school youth, Youth 13-24 yrs, In school youth, Children 6-12 yrs, People with Disabilities, Staff

Establish and sustain an enhanced monitoring, evaluation, and learning system., Train an additional 2,250 "community facilitators" in trauma healing and engagement in community problem-solving., Support the integration of trauma healing and non-violent community problem-solving in social and public institutions., Sustain support to existing Wozo-trained community facilitators and ongoing community change efforts., Launch a national advocacy campaign encouraging action by the public, agencies and authorities to address one trauma/violence issue selected as a common concern in Haiti on the basis of Wozo clubs and participants., Provide coaching support to the Wozo Director on matters related to leadership, strategic, and operational issues., Provide organizational development support to: a) Wozo's leadership development, teambuilding, and business development efforts, and b) Wozo's capabilities in communications, advocacy, knowledge management, learning, strategic planning, data analysis, program administration, and financial management.

WOZO Haiti is a leadership network that promotes the vision of a healed and peaceful society, engaging people of diverse backgrounds. It nurtures respect and dignity for human life that transforms social relations and systems. Created in 2010 after a crippling earthquake in the Port-au-Prince area, WOZO has expanded its services throughout the country. WOZO found that the earthquake provided a shared experience across Haiti that enabled all peoples to talk about traumas and problem-solving in new ways. From its beginning, WOZO has aimed to address the earthquake’s devastation as well as the traumas and related social challenges that have historically afflicted Haiti. Therefore, WOZO continues to address the violence that deeply affects urban and non-urban areas by teaching leaders nonviolent ways to resolve everyday problems and conflicts. WOZO now aims to serve its vision by expanding the availability of these resources for social change to partner institutions and organizations.
